narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I learned a core set of skills and processes on how to approach private equity investments. In class touched upon the topics of bankruptcy, non-investment grade bonds, corporate governance, public policy issues, leadership, and takeover laws. We also briefly assessed early stage investments.
modeling, legal aspects of finance, mechanics of deals, leadership, how companies work, and so much more
I learned the fundamentals of private equity investing, including how to evaluate investments, structure deals, write loan agreements, etc.
Principals of private equity, knowledge of debt agreements and leverage, and corporate law concepts important to private equity (loan covenants, etc.)
I learned skills relating to financial modeling, excel use, and finding applicable data while reading financial documents.
Fundamentals of debt structuring and covenants. Basic frameworks for investing in late-stage and growth-stage companies.
Understanding of the private equity sector in America
I learned financial modelling (LBO, M&A and others), and a lot about PE and VC investing. Also had the chance to brush up on the most recent trends and events in the financial markets in general.

The way in which PE firms are structured, how they operate. The structure of Bankruptcy law. A broad framework for evaluating PE investments at the venture, growth and late stages. Several applied case studies. A fantastic, broad overview of PE investing with a lot of detail available for interested students to dive more deeply into.

The course covers various stages of private equity deal flows and helps students answer what makes a good investment. The assignments engage students in assignments that dive deeps into term sheet structure, lbo and dcf models, late stage and early stage company business structure. I learned how to better read financial documents, synthesize provided information with a logical evaluation of every company's commercial system.

I learned all about the private equity process, from the basics of business fundamentals to structuring a deal in the "real world," both in early and late-stage investments. The material moved fast and was quite in depth. However, you are expected to come in with pretty significant modeling experience, since this is not taught.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments:
Strengths:
- Very useful class for anyone who wants to go into Private Equity. Everything we learned is useful for the interviews and recruiting process
- Preparing cases before class and discussing them in class

Weaknesses:
- Reading very detailed 70+ pages/class on a topic that is not as important was a waste of time in my opinion (I don't think that we need to understand all the details of bankruptcy law in order to become good investors). The professor claimed that most Private Equity associates don't know any of this, so it doesn't seem to be as important as the professor states.
- A midterm exam on topics covered is useless if it is just learning definitions, I think that the midterm should be structured like the take-home final exam (a case to work on over several days)
- Homework was given after every class for the next class. Given how much work this class is, it would be useful to be given homework for the next week, an not have 2 days to prepare for a case sometimes (Monday to Wednesday) and the same amount of work over several days until the next class (Wednesday to the following Monday)
- Too much work. Impossible to carefully spend time on all homework unless you want to pull an all nighter before every class or fail all your other classes
- Textbook (written by the professor) is too complicated and detailed to understand.
Teaches a lot about PE and its multifaceted nature, the course could benefit from teaching a bit more about modeling
This course is structured well. You will learn a lot but you have to be prepared to have a) very thick skin and b) the time to dedicate to the course.
This is a great course if thinking about private equity. It gives a good overview of the space and Professor Schmertzler is a very knowledge guy on many topics.
Strengths: case studies
The course gives a very thorough breakdown of methods used by private equity sponsors, but could do better to focus in on the most important things instead of broadly discussing everything.
Amazing class, and it was run very efficiently. The structure was ideal for the material. There are no suggestions I have at this time.

The class is really well structured and the content is very rich. Professor Schmertzler is really good at observing where the class is going and nudging people toward pedagogically meaningful directions. It would be great if more detailed, direct feedback is provided.
No weaknesses - this is an amazing course and Prof. Schmertzler does a lot to keep it that way, constantly updating the material and the coursework.

Professor Schmertzler is a fantastic educator. His teaching style is perhaps somewhat more blunt and to the point than what you may be used to at Yale, but it is clear that he cares deeply about his students' learning in the course and that his high expectations for the quality of work required make students engage deeply with the material. Schmertzler enjoys being provocative and asking questions in such a way that whatever answer you provide, he will raise questions/issues with your answer. This forces you to think for yourself and justify any arguments you make thoroughly - I found this to be refreshing in contrast to the typical "great comment, Johnny" that most professors give out regardless of what you say. If you say something that is bull hockey, Schmertzler will call you out on it. He also has a great sense of humor and many interesting anecdotes from his career.

Professor Michael Schmertzler is naturally talented at sharing his experience, synthesize current deals news, and helping students answer lingering questions about the private equity textbook. The course could be improved by having a TF who could give students more frequent feedback.

The professor is absolutely great, as he is immensely experienced and brings a lot of interest and experience to every single class. The material is also interesting and directly applicable (perhaps in the workplace or just in daily life). I do wish there was a bit less cold-calling in the class, as it could sometimes feel hostile/stressful early in the semester (probably worsened by the virtual format). However, the professor took feedback and improved this completely by the end of the semester.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments:
Succeeded:
- Discussion-based class was helpful in keeping all of us engaged 

Weaknesses:
- A lot of group work. That was hard to do with other students remotely, especially those who were in different time zones
- Classes not recorded, so some students had to be up until 3am to attend the seminar
The course was actually very engaging despite being virtual.
Doing in class group projects was poorly coordinated and sometimes students were left out.
The virtual seminars worked extremely well given the circumstances. I also enjoyed the coffee chats
The negotiations among students are a little bit tough considering that people are at all different time zones and have their schedules.

Enforced live attendance made it almost as good as a live, in-person seminar would be. Having us keep the cameras on and cold-calling on students during discussion made sure everyone was engaged and ready.
Some kind of office hours / more options for speaking with the professor one on one would be a nice addition.

Group work was almost impossible in this class, since it needed to be done quickly and virtually. Since some of these assignments were multi-round mock "negotiations," there were a lot of difficulties with the virtual format. Maybe some alternate platform besides zoom could be used. Other than that, everything was great.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: This class is amazing in that you will learn A LOT. However, be prepared to spend most of your time all semester working on this class and teaching yourself the material.

You will learn a lot from this class if you put in the work and do all the homework (and you actually have to because Professor Schmertzler cold calls and can easily tell if you arent prepared). There is a lot of casework and collaborative group work that was actually very helpful and engaging. 

You also need to be prepared to stand your ground. The course moves quickly and Prof Schmertzler has a very intense teaching style that can be intimidating even for the most prepared students. I think this class was a good exercise in learning how to be assertive and defend your ideas. That being said, it definitely felt a little too aggressive at times. But you will learn a lot, so stand your ground and try your best not to feel like an imposter - trust me, everyone feels that way. You deserve to be there and Prof Schmertzler recognizes peoples potential even if they might not think so.
Yes, it is one of the best courses to enhance financial knowledge and modeling skills, but be prepared to do a lot of work.

If you can handle a large workload and have a finance mentality, this course will give you an edge over your analyst class in any finance role. I strongly recommend you take it. 

If you cannot handle the workload, cannot take criticism well, and/or do not have a diligent work ethic, you should reconsider taking the course. This is not the course where you can rush through the material and finish the work 5 minutes before class.

Highly recommend it if you are interested in getting a systematic way of looking at late-stage and some early-stage investments. There are lots of case studies that help you crystalize the takeaways (so modeling skill is a must).
Absolutely. A lot of work but its worth it
Yes, absolutely take this class - the best course on finance I've taken during my time at Yale. Prof. Schmertzler is a star and super dedicated to teaching. Be ready to work hard, though.

Absolutely. If you are interested in learning about the PE industry (and fundamental evaluation of companies from an investment perspective more generally) this is a great class. You will have to spend a lot of time on the course material and work damn hard, but it is most definitely worth it. 
Without any hyperbole, this was one of the highlights of my time at Yale (quite possibly the best class I have taken at Yale) and you learn an immense amount.

Yes, I would 100% recommend this course to any student who wants a better understanding of investment analysis in private equity, venture capital, and even future entrepreneurs who want to understand how to create a business structure and select leadership that would get the company funded. It is a very challenging course for those without previous finance-oriented experiences, yet if you're up for a great learning curve that would potentially help your corporate job in the real world, this would be a great choice.

Yes, take this class, but only if you have actual interest in going into private equity, venture capital, or something similar in your career. The workload is pretty high and it will be a miserable time if you don't enjoy the material.
